review.title: A Joint Indoor WLAN Localization and Outlier Detection Scheme Using LASSO and Elastic-Net Optimization Techniques
review.abstract: In this paper, we introduce two indoor Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) positioning methods using augmented sparse recovery algorithms. These schemes render a sparse user's position vector, and in parallel, minimize the distance between the online measurement and radio map. The overall localization scheme for both methods consists of three steps: 1) coarse localization, obtained from comparing the online measurements with clustered radio map. A novel graph-based method is proposed to cluster the offline fingerprints. In the online phase, a Region Of Interest (ROI) is selected within which we search for the user's location; 2) Access Point (AP) selection; and 3) fine localization through the novel sparse recovery algorithms. Since the online measurements are subject to inordinate measurement readings, called outliers, the sparse recovery methods are modified in order to jointly estimate the outliers and user's position vector. The outlier detection procedure identifies the APs whose readings are either not available or erroneous. The proposed localization methods have been tested with Received Signal Strength (RSS) measurements in a typical office environment and the results show that they can localize the user with significantly high accuracy and resolution which is superior to the results from competing WLAN fingerprinting localization methods.

sections.heading: 5 IMPLEMENTATION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: This section deals with the experimental evaluation of the proposed methods in a real environment. The mobile recording device and the environment are discussed and the results are analyzed.

sections.heading: 5.1 RSSI Capturing Device
sections.text: Because a large number of handheld mobile devices run on the Linux-based Android operating system, the RSS fingerprints were collected using a proprietary Android application on a Samsung tablet (Galaxy Tab A) that runs on Android Lollipop 5.0.2 with the inherent android.net.wifi package.The wifi package provides the ability to manually set the reading interval of the device Network Interface Card (NIC), but our experiment showed that the readings are repeated for short sampling times.One possible reason could be that the device has an inherent delay in refreshing the NIC buffer. That's why we set the device to record the RSSI readings once per second and store the MAC address and RSS in a database.

sections.heading: 5.2 Environment Setup
sections.text: Real data was obtained from the third floor of the five-story Applied Engineering and Technology (AET) building at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). The measurement site dimensions are 300 ft x 35 ft, comparable to those reported in [36], [40]. The layout of the experimental area is illustrated in Fig. 2 and the green circles show the locations of the fingerprints. The area is representative of an indoor office environment with a complex wireless distribution pattern based on research laboratories, offices, libraries and study areas, and has a high commute rate. For fingerprints, the RP sites can be drawn from a point process in which the position of the RPs is derived from a probability distribution. This method leads to points along the busiest routes. sections.text: During the offline phase, the area was divided into a total of 192 grid points and we collected 100 samples per grid point at four device orientations over a three-week period. Localization error of a locating system is strongly influenced by RSS variations, the number of APs and the subset of RPs and APs selected in the localization system. To alleviate the time-varying RSS fingerprints, the recorded offline readings have been averaged over time, as explained in Section 2. Online measurement is recorded once. The assumption of taking multiple online measurements is unrealistic in existing localization methods unless the user stays at that location during the online acquisition.

sections.heading: 5.5 Offline Clustering
sections.text: The performance of the sparse recovery localization approaches strongly depends on the number of online measurements (APs) and the number of predictors (RPs). In CS-based localization, the number of measurements should be in the order of the Log-N value to ensure a clear recovery of the position vector. However, if the measurements of the radio map are correlated, the required number of measurements should be significantly increased and therefore more APs should be used for a good, sparse recovery. This problem is alleviated in LASSO and GLMNET localization, as each has its own recovery scheme for correlated predictors. Clustering brings a twofold benefit to localization. Since the solution should be found on the number of predictors (RPs), clustering helps to reduce the number of RPs, the columns of errors of the LPs, and thus the number of APs needed for good recovery, which also reduces the size of the LAPs.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have shown that a simple cluster algorithm can efficiently cluster the RPs when the cluster scheme includes overlapping clusters connected by neighboring clusters. In addition, the two proposed localization approaches, LASSO and GLMNET, are able to deliver significantly lower localization errors because they also minimize residuals between the radio map and online measurement. Furthermore, they are not negatively affected by the correlated fingerprints of the radio map, but benefit from the similarity of the RSS readings and do not require orthogonalization pre-processing. We have also shown that if the APs contain outliers, as is likely, the positioning error would be high. Therefore, by augmenting the proposed method together, our methods can detect, modify the outlier and estimate the position of the user.

sections.heading: 7 FUTURE WORK
sections.text: The comparison of many different localization techniques is hampered by the lack of standardized representative data that can be used for fair comparisons.The authors plan an open data repository of their data that can be used by the community for comparative studies.The radio map addressed in this thesis has four orientations.The proposed localization scheme integrates the available information from all the orientations described, but there may be alternative formulations for dealing with different orientations, which is of great interest for further studies.In addition, the experimental results in the previous section showed that the fine localization algorithms represent fluctuations in localization accuracy for a small number of APs. An interest of our future research is to find the causes of this phenomenon and provide more stable localization mechanisms with a smaller number of APs.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we introduce two indoor Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) positioning methods using augmented sparse recovery algorithms. These schemes render a sparse user’s position vector, and in parallel, minimize the distance between the online measurement and radio map. The overall localization scheme for both methods consists of three steps: 1) coarse localization, obtained from comparing the online measurements with clustered radio map. A novel graph-based method is proposed to cluster the offline fingerprints. In the online phase, a Region Of Interest (ROI) is selected within which we search for the user’s location; 2) Access Point (AP) selection; and 3) fine localization through the novel sparse recovery algorithms. Since the online measurements are subject to inordinate measurement readings, called outliers, the sparse recovery methods are modified in order to jointly estimate the outliers and user’s position vector. The outlier detection procedure identifies the APs whose readings are either not available or erroneous. The proposed localization methods have been tested with Received Signal Strength (RSS) measurements in a typical office environment and the results show that they can localize the user with significantly high accuracy and resolution which is superior to the results from competing WLAN fingerprinting localization methods.
